results.title: The Brass choir: an instructional sound film
results.brief_description: A fine and artfully “composed” documentary film of the orchestra in performance. Shows a sensitive demonstration of the tone color of instruments from the orchestra’s brass section with excerpts from Beethoven’s 5th Symphony, the Nocturne from Mendelson’s Midsummer Night’s Dream, Wagner’s Tannhauser.

results.title: The Brain Puzzle (TEFC)
results.brief_description: The ability of the brain to physically alter in response to external events accounts for the partial recovery of stroke and head injury victims. This program looks at the possibility for the brain to speed up these recovery processes.

results.title: The Boys from Boise
results.brief_description: There were a few original musicals written for TV in the 1940s, but viewers were few and these shows are essentially forgotten. Most experts agree that the first original televised musical was The Boys From Boise, broadcast by the DuMont Network in 1944.

constellations_other.name: Boom mics, Clara Bow and musicals
constellations_other.description: The microphone was called the "terror of the studios" when sound films were introduced in the late 1920s, but after initial resistance Hollywood fully embraced the new technology.

results.description: There were a few original musicals written for television in the 1940s, but viewers were few and these shows are essentially forgotten. Most experts agree that the first original televised musical was The Boys From Boise, broadcast by the DuMont Network on Sept. 28, 1944. It had a score by Sam Medoff and told the story of a troupe of showgirls stranded on an Idaho ranch. Although well received, it boasted no stars, turned out no hit songs and started no trends. - musicals101.com
description_for_label: There were a few original musicals written for television in the 1940s, but viewers were few and these shows are essentially forgotten. Most experts agree that the first original televised musical was The Boys From Boise, broadcast by the DuMont Network on Sept. 28, 1944. It had a score by Sam Medoff and told the story of a troupe of showgirls stranded on an Idaho ranch. Although well received, it boasted no stars, turned out no hit songs and started no trends. - musicals101.com

results.title: The Boy from Coober Pedy
results.creator_credit: Eugene Schlusser and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: The story of a family who go to live in Coober Pedy, South Australia. Shows the ways in which the family live in, and adapt to, their new environment, initially living in a caravan while their underground home is completed. The excavation and creation of this house, ideally suited to the climate, is shown. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: The Boy and the North Wind
results.brief_description: A puppet animation film about greed and justice. A young boy receives three presents from the North Wind and each one is stolen by a greedy landlord. Finally the North Wind gives the boy a present that punishes the greedy landlord.

results.title: The Book Place

constellations_other.name: Learning through play
constellations_other.description: Alexander Stitt and Bruce Weatherhead’s Zoetrope to Cinemascope educated children about the moving image through posters, cut-outs, puzzles and games, but moving image works have also been used to educate and entertain kids about all aspects of life.

results.description: The Book Place was an educational TV show for children, which aired on the Seven Network from 1991 to 2003. The show was originally presented by former host of Fat Cat and Friends, Lynn Weston with Brenton Whittle, and Andy Armstrong, with Michael Scheld as the Bookworm.
description_for_label: The Book Place was an educational TV show for children, which aired on the Seven Network from 1991 to 2003. The show was originally presented by former host of Fat Cat and Friends, Lynn Weston with Brenton Whittle, and Andy Armstrong, with Michael Scheld as the Bookworm.

results.title: The Bonne Bell Mini Marathon
results.creator_credit: Yvonne Hannemann and Wombat Productions, Inc.
results.brief_description: A film about the Bonne Bell Mini Marathon, an all-women event which took place in Central Park, New York. Hundreds of women of all ages took part - from serious runners to those who entered just for the enjoyment.

results.title: The Bolero [Ed. version]
results.creator_credit: Allan Miller and Allan Miller Productions
results.brief_description: An exciting study of Ravel’s composition “Bolero” with the subtle meanings and accents polished to a brilliant interpretation by members of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra with Zubin Mehta. The film involves the viewer in each musician’s approach to his part in individual preparation and general rehearsals prior to the final performance. It also gives some insight into Mehta’s perspective on musical values in the composition. (An edited version of Title 001358)
